Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Computational Models and Algorithms for Differential Network Analysis in Systems Biology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Computational Models and Algorithms
for Differential Network Analysis in Systems Biology

PI: Mehmet Koyut√ºrk, Case Western Reserve University

An important challenge in life sciences, emerging from various successful genome sequencing efforts, is the characterization of molecular mechanisms that underlie phenotypic differences (variation in observable characteristics of biological systems). These variations include developmental stages, disease, and evolution. Molecular sequence and expression datasets have been used effectively to identify frequently mutated genes and the relative abundance/lack of their products in cells carrying the phenotype of interest. While the role of contextual information, manifested in networks of biomolecular interactions is widely acknowledged, lack of high-quality data has impeded the development and use of network-based analyses. Recent high-throughput methods for network inference hold tremendous potential for network-based phenotype analysis. However, existing computational methods are in relative infancy. The primary objective of this project is the development of computational models and algorithms that enable integration of disparate datasets (gene sequences, gene expression, protein expression, protein interactions) for phenotypic characterization.

Network-based modeling of phenotypic differences gives rise to deep intellectual questions relating to computational abstraction, algorithm design, and biological validation. These challenges are exacerbated by the incomplete, static, and noisy nature of available network data. The proposed research aims to overcome these difficulties through innovative use of combinatorial, probabilistic, and algebraic methods, including the following: (i) combinatorial modeling of coordinate changes in the expression of multiple interacting genes, (ii) probabilistic modeling of the crosstalk in biomolecular networks, for statistically sound evaluation of functional association between multiple genes and proteins, and (iii) algebraic modeling of information flow in the cell, to make indirect inferences on the effects of multiple genetic perturbations. The resulting computational tools will be integrated into frequently accessed application frameworks, including Cytoscape, R, and Matlab, used extensively by domain scientists at Case Center for Proteomics and Bioinformatics, for testing, validation, and calibration, and subsequently disseminated to the broader scientific community.

The proposed career plan also incorporates major educational and outreach initiatives that build on the interdisciplinary nature of proposed research. These initiatives include (i) novel instructional techniques based on active learning, (ii) continued development of a Computer Science education platform, TELESCOPE, for the purpose of illustrating basic algorithmic and problem solving principles, (iii) incorporation of TELESCOPE into outreach efforts, targeting K-12 schools, CWRUs TRIO programs for low income pre-college students, and CWRUs Equinox summer program, (iv) programs for student involvement (particularly minority and female) in outreach efforts, (v) development of new interdisciplinary courses and degree programs at undergraduate and graduate levels, and (vi) continued involvement of undergraduate students in research projects.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to develop computational methods and algorithms for network-based analysis of biological data. These data are obtained from model organisms, cell lines, and patients to identify molecular markers for diseases. However, since too many factors are measured, the number of samples is limited, and the data is noisy, it is usually difficult to dissect biologically relevant patterns from noise. The methods developed by this project make use of “biological networks” to help separate the patterns from noise by grounding the identified markers in biological function.

Intellectual Merit. In the last ten years, in many biomedical labs, functional interpretations of biomarkers are done using “pathway databases”, which represent established knowledge on well-characterized biological processes. Since these pathways are limited to established knowledge, they are not very useful in extracting novel information and generating new hypothesis. “Biological network” data, on the other hand, represent experimentally or computationally identified functional links between biomolecules, so they provide an opportunity to extract previously unknown patterns. However, since the space of combinations of these molecules and their interplay is very large, utilization of network requires computationally more elaborate models. In its five years, this project developed various computational methods to address these challenges and establish “network-based analysis” as a framework that complements “pathway analysis” in biomedical research. This project led to the development of many computational methods, including network-based algorithms for candidate disease gene prioritization, algorithms for the identification of combinatorially dysregulated protein subnetworks in cancer, algorithms for integrating multiple levels of biological data in cancer, and development of algorithms for link prediction.

Borader Impacts. The application of the methods developed by this project to specific biomedical problems led to the discovery of novel biological knowledge. The application of the methods developed by this project led to the identification of proteomic markers of survival in patients with brain tumors, identification of novel proteins that play a role in the Wnt signaling pathway (a fundamental pathway in development and disease progression), and the identification of the common biomolecular bases of neurological disorders. Some of the methods that have been developed were also commercialized by NeoProteomics, Inc., a biotechnology start-up that provides data analysis service in pharmaceutical research and development. Additionally, this project contributed to the development of the Systems Biology and Bioinformatics programs at Case Western Reserve University, as well as the training and career development of nine students, including Ph.Ds, master’s students, and undergraduate students. Finally, an outreach program titled “Computer Science, Puzzles, and Genomics”, which presents bioinformatics problems in the form of games and puzzles, was developed and was presented to K-12 students in the Cleveland Metropolitan School District and various K-12 outreach events that target female and minority students at Case Western Reserve University.     

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2016
Modified by: Mehmet Koyuturk
